Fig. 1 FEG-SEM images (a and b) and EDX mapping analysis (c) of M1 catalyst. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 FEG-SEM images (a and b) and EDX mapping analysis (c) of M2 catalyst. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Evolution of (a) the conversion and (b) the selectivity values and the P/O ratio versus the number of contacts in LB arrangements at 15 h of reaction. Reaction conditions: m(M1 +M2)= 1.20 g, P = 30 bar, T = 400 °C, H2/CO/Ar= 53/21/26, WHSV(xLB(y))= 5 L.h-1.g-1 and WHSV(for M1 alone)= 10 L.h-1.g-1 (the P/O ratio represents the proportion of paraffins relative to olefins). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Evolution of the conversion (a) and evolution of the selectivity values and the P/O ratio (b) versus the M2 content in SRM arrangements at 15 h of reaction. Reaction conditions: m(M1 +M2)= 1.20 g, P = 30 bar, T = 400 °C, H2/CO/Ar= 53/21/26, WHSV= 5 L.h-1.g-1 (the P/O ratio represents the proportion of paraffins relative to olefins). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) two-dimensional multicomponent packing, (b) tetrahedral subunits (Orange and yellow spheres represent M1 and M2, respectively.), (c) evolution of contact concentrations and (d) evolution of the normalized M1-M2 contact concentration and the normalized XCOgain of SRM versus M2 content (with rM1=rM2=65.0 µm, ρ M 1 = 1.23 g cm − 3 and ρ M 2 = 0.94 g cm − 3 ). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) FEG-SEM image, (b) Cu (red) and P (yellow) EDX mapping analysis of reduced SRM(0.50) catalyst, Cu (red) and P (yellow) EDX mapping of the surface of (c) M1 and (d) M2 grains and (e) schematic representation of the reduced SRM(0.50) catalyst. Fig. 8 Syngas conversion into light hydrocarbons over bifunctional catalyst: Effect of the density of contact between Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 and SAPO-34 Valentin L’hospital a Christophe Coudercy b Ludovic Pinard a Julie Rousseau a Stéphane Loridant b Anthony Le Valant a ⁎ a IC2MP, UMR 7285 CNRS, Université de Poitiers, 4 Rue Michel Brunet, 86022 Poitiers cedex, France IC2MP, UMR 7285 CNRS, Université de Poitiers 4 Rue Michel Brunet Poitiers cedex 86022 France IC2MP, UMR 7285 CNRS, Université de Poitiers, 4 Rue Michel Brunet, 86022 Poitiers cedex, (France). b Univ Lyon, Université Claude Bernard-Lyon 1, CNRS, IRCELYON-UMR 5256, 2 av. Einstein Villeurbanne Cedex F-69626 France Univ Lyon, Université Claude Bernard-Lyon 1, CNRS, IRCELYON-UMR 5256, 2 av. A. Einstein, F-69626 Villeurbanne Cedex, France. ⁎ Corresponding author. A series of hybrid catalysts with different catalytic bed dispositions (layer bed and simple random mixture) of Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 and SAPO-34 have been adopted and evaluated in syngas conversion into light C2-C4 hydrocarbons. An effect of the proximity between the two solids on the CO hydrogenation activity was demonstrated. A sphere contact quantification model was developed to estimate the concentration of contact between them for any simple random mixture. Comparing the evolution of gain of CO conversion (or hydrocarbon yield) with the theoretical results, it was shown that the density of contact was identified as the key factor for the catalytic performances (contact-activity relationship). Finally, the knowledge of the contact morphology, determined by FEG-SEM, allowed proposing the NH3-TPD as method characterizing the concentration of contact. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Syngas Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 SAPO-34 Hybrid catalyst Methanol Light C2-C4 hydrocarbons Sphere contact quantification model NH3-TPD Contact-activity relationship 1 Introduction Light (C2-C4) hydrocarbons are important chemical building blocks for a variety of useful derivatives in the petrochemical and chemical industries [1,2]. They are presently produced worldwide in huge amounts mostly by steam cracking of naphta which is highly energy-consuming process. C2-C4 hydrocarbons synthesis from syngas (a mixture of CO and H2) is attractive since renewable carbon resources (biomass, wastes, CO2) are expected to gradually replace fossil fuels [3]. Fischer-Tropsch (FT) synthesis is the traditional process of converting syngas to hydrocarbons [4]. However, the FT process is limited by the Anderson−Schultz−Flory (ASF) distribution and contain a small yield of C2-C4 hydrocarbons [5,6]. A two-step process including methanol synthesis (Reaction 1) followed by methanol-to-olefins (MTO, Reaction 2) process is commercially available to produce light hydrocarbons but development of a more energetically and costly-efficient direct process is needed [7]. (Reactionn 1) CO + 2 H 2 ⇌ CH 3 OH (Reactionn 2) n CH 3 OH → C n H 2 n + n H 2 O The advantage of the single-step process is the achievement of both reactions (Reactions 1 and 2) in one reactor in order to simplify the process route and equipment [4]. This process is possible using a so-called hybrid or bifunctional catalyst. The bifunctional catalyst corresponds to a physical mixture of methanol synthesis catalyst (Cu-ZnO-Al2O3) and zeotype (SAPO-34), can lead to the formation of light hydrocarbons from syngas via methanol as reactional intermediate [4,8,9]. The main advantage of the single-step process is the elimination of the restriction of methanol synthesis by the thermodynamic equilibrium shift (drain-off mechanism) [10]. It can be assumed therefore that the proximity between methanol synthesis catalyst and SAPO-34 (where the methanol is converted) plays a significant role in the catalytic performances (high. CO conversion) and in the hydrocarbon selectivity [9]. In the present work, we investigated the activity of hybrid catalyst for the CO hydrogenation into hydrocarbons (HC) as a function concentration of contact between methanol synthesis catalyst (M1) and SAPO-34 (M2). In order to evaluate the effect of the proximity between M1 and M2, different catalytic bed dispositions (layer bed, denoted LB, and simple random mixture, denoted SRM) of both components have been adopted. Using a similar methodology as previously described [11,12], we built contact–reactivity relationship on the basis of catalytic observations. The results led us to formulate hypotheses concerning the morphology of the contacts, as well as the development of a mathematical model for sphere contact quantification in randomly packed binary mixtures. Experimental data were compared with theoretical calculations to validate the model. Finally, the knowledge of the contact morphology, determined by field emission gun scanning electron microscope (FEG-SEM), allowed proposing a method to characterize the concentration of contact of each hybrid catalyst. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials 2.1.1 Methanol synthesis catalyst A commercially available methanol synthesis copper-based catalyst (M1) was used. This is a material developed by Johnson Matthey and sold by Alfa Aesar (a Johnson Matthey company) in the form of 5.4 mm × 3.6 mm pellets. These pellets were crushed and sized to 160 − 100 µm (in this form, the apparent density of the M1 (denoted ρ M 1 ) material is equal to 1.23 g cm-3 and the radius of the M1 material is rM1 = 65.0 µm). 2.1.2 SAPO-34 A SAPO-34 zeolite (M2) in the form of fine powder was purchased from ACS Material. It was pelletized, crushed and sized to 160 − 100 µm (in this form, the apparent density of the M2 (denoted ρ M 2 ) material is equal to 0.94 g cm-3 and the radius of the M2 material is rM2 = 65.0 µm). 2.1.3 Hybrid catalysts 2.1.3.1 Layer bed arrangements The layer bed arrangements (denoted xLB(y), where x and y represent the number of layers and the number of contacts, in terms of contact section between M1 and M2, respectively) are presented in the Table S1. The same amount of M1 (160−100 µm) and M2 (160 −100 µm) reference materials was used for each of LB arrangement. The differences between the LB arrangements are the number of alternating layers between M1 and M2, resulting a change in the number of contacts (see Table S1). 2.1.3.2 Simple random mixture arrangements The simple random mixture arrangements (denoted SRM(x), where x represents the M2 proportion) were prepared by simple mixing M1 (160−100 µm) and M2 (160−100 µm) reference materials with different weight ratios. The characteristics of SRM arrangements are presented in the Table S2. 2.2 Characterization of materials The morphology of the M1, M2 and reduced SRM(0.50) (reduced in the same conditions as the catalytic test, see paragraph 2.3) catalysts were studied using a field emission gun scanning electron microscope (FEG-SEM) 7900F from JEOL. This microscope is equipped with an Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectrometer (EDS) from Brücker (with Esprit software) allowing the mapping of the Cu, Zn, Al, Mg, Si, P, O and C contents. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was used for the determination of the metal content in M1 and M2 samples. The measurements were performed with a Perkin Elmer Optima 2000DV spectrometer. The M1 sample was previously dissolved in an acidic mixture of HNO3 and HCl to perform the analyses for Cu, Zn, Al and Mg. The M2 sample was dissolved into H2SO4 +HNO3 +HF at boiling point to perform the analyses for Al and P. For the Si determination, the solid was fused with lithium tetraborate into a Pt‐Au crucible at 1100 °C. The obtained solid was then dissolved into HCl. The textural properties of the M1 and M2 catalysts were determined by adsorption–desorption of nitrogen at the temperature of liquid nitrogen (−196 °C, 77 K) using a Micromeritics Tristar and ASAP 2000 instruments. Before measuring, the M1 was degassed at 250 °C for 4 h and the M2 was heated at 350 °C overnight. The SBET surface areas were calculated according to the method of Brunauer, Emmet and Teller (BET). The Smicro surface area and Vmicro volume pore of M2 catalyst were determined with the t-plot method. The Sexter external surface area corresponds to the difference between SBET and Smicro and the Vexter external pore volume to the difference between the total pore volume and the Vmicro. In situ X-ray diffractograms were carried out using a D8 advance diffractometer in Bragg-Brentano configuration equipped with a Cu anode (Cu Kα radiation: 0.154184 nm) and a LynxEye XET 1-D detector. The samples were mounted in an atmosphere-controlled Anton Paar XRK 900 reactor chamber. X-ray diffractograms were recorded in pure H2 (20 mL·min-1) before and after reduction at 400 °C for 30 min with a step of 0.03° (2θ) and a counting time per step of 2 s A Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 apparatus was employed for the temperature programmed reduction (TPR) measurement. Approximately 100 mg of freshly M1 catalyst was introduced between two quartz wool balls into a quartz U-shaped tube. The TPR experiments was carried out in 10% H2/Ar flowing at a rate of 30 NmL min-1 with a temperature increase from 30° to 400°C at 5 °C min-1 using a programmable temperature controller. Hydrogen consumption was monitored by a TCD detector. The ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) measurement was undertaken using a homemade apparatus equipped with a TCD detector. For the analysis, 250 mg of catalyst (M1, M2, LB and SRM arrangements) was placed in quartz reactor between two quartz wool layers. The catalyst was pretreated as follows: the temperature of the catalyst bed was increased to 400 °C (5 °C min-1) under a H2 flow (30 NmL min-1) and this temperature was maintained for 30 min. Next, the sample was purged with He at the same temperature and duration. Finally, the catalyst was cooled down to 100 °C and this temperature was maintained for 30 min. Adsorption of ammonia was then carried out at 100 °C for 60 min. After purging with helium for 60 min, the analysis was carried out at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 from 100° to 700°C. In situ DRIFT spectra were achieved with a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Scientific) equipped with Praying Mantis™ High Temperature Reaction Chamber (Harrick, model HVC-DRP-4) and MCT detector cooled by liquid N2. The spectral resolution was 4 cm-1. The temperature gradient between the regulation thermocouple and the upper part of the powder sample was previously determined and corrected. The samples were firstly pre-treated at 400 °C under 20 mL.min-1 of He flow for 1 h before NH3 chimisorption under 30 mL.min-1 of 1%NH3-He flow and purging under 20 mL.min-1 of He flow for 1 h. Spectra were then recorded from room temperature up to 400 °C. 2.3 Catalysis Catalytic performances of M1, M2, LB and SRM arrangements were compared in a continuous fixed‐bed stainless steel reactor (L = 400 mm, Øint = 6.35 mm). The details of the different arrangements used in this study are illustrated in Tables S1 and S2. For 2LB(0) arrangement, M1 and M2 were separated with a layer of SiC (0.60 g). Before reaction, the catalyst was pre‐treated in situ at 400 °C for 30 min (heating rate of 5 °C min‐1) under a flow of pure H2 (1.8 NL h‐1) at atmospheric pressure. Then, the reactor was purged with argon and the pressure was increased to 30 bar. The reactor was then flushed with the reactant gas mixture (H2/CO/Ar:53/21/26, 6 NL h‐1) at 400 °C. The outlet flow was decompressed and periodically injected in an Agilent 7890 A gas chromatograph (GC) connected online. All the lines connecting the reactor with the GC were kept at 200 °C to avoid product condensation. The GC was equipped with three channels: the first one consisted of two series connected of HP PLOT 5 A molecular sieve column (for H2 and CO) and a HP PLOT Q molecular sieve column (for CO2 and H2O) connected to a TCD detector, while the second channel consisted of a HP INNOWAX capillary column (for methanol) connected to a FID detector and finally the third channel consisted of a GS‐Q capillary column (for hydrocarbons) connected to another FID detector. The CO conversion was calculated using the following equation (Eq.1): (1) X CO ( % ) = F CO , in − F CO , out F CO , in × 100 where F CO , in and F CO , out are the molar inlet and outlet CO flows. The selectivity to a product ( i ) is calculated by comparing the molar flow of the product ( i ) and the total amount of CO converted (Eq.2): (2) S i = n i × F i F CO , in − F CO , out × 100 where n i and F i are the carbon atom numbers in the product ( i ) and the molar flow of the product ( i ). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 M1 and M2 characterizations 3.1.1 Morphological, textural and physicochemical properties of methanol synthesis catalyst (M1) FEG-SEM images of the M1 commercial methanol synthesis catalyst are shown in Fig. 1. The morphology of catalyst M1 behaves like irregular particles. Fig. 1 shows the results of EDX elemental analysis of the obtained M1 material. The oxygen, aluminum, copper, zinc, magnesium and carbon elements were detected. The composition of the M1 commercial methanol catalyst was also determined by ICP-OES: the weight percentages of CuO, ZnO, Al2O3 and MgO are 55.3, 21.7, 7.8 and 1.1 wt% (the missing 14.1 wt% corresponding to carbon and water), respectively (Table S3). The BET surface area (SBET)and pore volume (Vexter) of the M1 compound are approximately 97 m2 g-1 and 0.20 cm3 g-1 (Table S3), respectively. XRD patterns of fresh and reduced M1 are shown in Fig. S1. Fresh M1 catalyst exhibit crystallized phases of CuO (tenorite structure), ZnO (zincite structure), (Cu0.8Zn0.2)2(OH)2(CO3) (zincian malachite structure) and carbon (graphitic structure). No phase containing Al2O3 or MgO was detected with XRD, due likely to amorph forms. After reduction under H2 at 400 °C, CuO is fully reduced to metallic copper whereas ZnO stays in its zincite form. The reducibility of M1 catalyst was also evaluated by H2-TPR. The TPR profile is shown in Fig. S2. This profile is characterized by the main peak centered at 241 °C and ascribed to the reduction of CuO to metallic Cu. The amount of H2 consumption (VH2) and the H2/Cu ratio are reported in Table S3. According to the stoichiometry of the CuO reduction ( CuO + H 2 → Cu + H 2 O ), the value of H2/Cu molar ratio, equal to one, indicates that 100% of copper is reduced to a metallic state under the reaction conditions, which is in accordance with the reduced M1 XRD measurement. 3.1.2 Morphological and textural properties of SAPO-34 (M2) The morphology of the M2 SAPO-34 commercial material is shown in Fig. 2. The M2 grains behave like a stack of micro-scale cubes (Fig. 2a and b). This cubic morphology is characteristic of the chabazite structure. Fig. 2c shows the results of EDX elemental analysis of the M2 material. The oxygen, aluminum, silicon, and phosphorus elements were detected. As can be seen, the distribution of the elements is very homogenous on the surface of M2 sample. The composition of the M2 SAPO-34 commercial material, determined by ICP-OES, is 8.9, 34.1 and 36.1 wt% (the missing 20.9 wt% corresponding to water) for SiO2, Al2O3 and P2O5, respectively (Table S4), with a Si/Al ratio equal to 0.22. The XRD pattern, displayed in Fig. S3, shows the typical diffraction peaks assigned to the chabazite structure at 9.6, 13.2, 16.2, 20.8, 26.0, and 31.1°. The SBET surface area and the Vexter external pore volume of the M2 are approximately 475 m2 g-1 and 0.03 cm3 g-1 (Table S4). The Smicro surface area and the Vmicro micropore volume are 463 m2 g-1 and 0.23 cm3 g-1, respectively. 3.2 Catalytic performances 3.2.1 M1 +M2 arrangements 3.2.1.1 Catalytic performances with layered bed (LB) arrangements The impact of the contact concentration between M1 and M2 is investigated using the different layered bed arrangements present in the Table S1. The performance of M1 and different catalytic layered bed arrangements at 15 h of reaction is shown in Fig. 3 (the evolution of the CO conversion and the product selectivities versus the time on stream is presented in Fig. S4). The M1 catalyzed the conversion of syngas to CH4, CO2 and hydrocarbons (denoted HC, mostly C2H6) with selectivities of approximately 45%, 40% and 10%, respectively. The CO conversion (denoted XCO) is approximately 7% (with WHSV=10 L.h-1.g-1, see Fig. 3a); and methanol (denoted MeOH) and dimethylether (denoted DME) traces are observed (Fig. 3b). These results clearly indicate that, under our experimental conditions, M1 favors the methanation and Water Gas Shift (WGS) reactions at the expense of methanol synthesis reaction, which is also in agreement with the thermodynamic equilibrium data presented in Table S5. No activity is observed for M2 alone (not presented here). When the M2 catalyst is associated with the M1 catalyst, without contact (2LB(0) arrangement, where M1 and M2 are separated from each other by a 1 cm thick layer of SiC), the CO conversion (Fig. 3a) and the CH4 and CO2 selectivities (Fig. 3b) are not changed compared to the test with the M1 catalyst alone. However, the disappearance of MeOH and DME is observed in favor of hydrocarbons. When the both catalysts are in contact (2LB(1), 4LB(3), 6LB(5), 8LB(7) and 10LB(9) arrangements), an increase in CO conversion (Fig. 3a) and HC selectivity (mostly C3H8) and a decrease in CH4 selectivity are observed (Fig. 3b, the CO2 selectivity is constant for all the catalytic tests). This phenomenon is amplified with the increase in the number of contacts between M1 and M2 layers. The formation of hydrocarbons is explained by the transformation of methanol intermediate formed over M1 into hydrocarbons over M2 acid sites, thus inhibiting the CO methanation and/or the hydrogenation of MeOH into CH4 over M1[13]. The intimacy between both materials leads to a strong increase in the proportion of paraffins relative to olefins (see the P/O ratio in Fig. 3b), indicating the hydrogenation of the olefins. Hydrogen spillover (from M1 to M2) and/or olefins spillover (from M2 to M1) and/or the hydrogenation of olefins by crossing through a layer of M1 would probably explain this [14,15]. It is possible to estimate the gain of CO conversion (denoted XCOgain), induced by the proximity between M1 and M2, by subtracting the CO conversion value of the xLB(y) catalyst (denoted XCO) with the value of M1 catalyst (denoted XCOM1), according with the following equation Eq.3: (3) XCOgain = XCO - XCOM1 with XCOM1 = 7%. The XCOgain (see Fig. 3a) scales linearly with the number of contacts, with an interception at zero. This result clearly evidences that the XCOgain is directly correlated with the M1-M2 contact concentration. This proximity eliminates restriction of methanol synthesis by the thermodynamic equilibrium shift and enhanced the CO conversion (and therefore the production of HC). 3.2.1.2 Catalytic performances with simple random mixture (SRM) arrangements In order to improve the CO conversion, different simple random mixtures of M1 and M2 were made. Different compositions of these SRM arrangements were used to vary the contact concentration between M1 and M2. The same total amount of M1 +M2 catalysts was used for each of SRM arrangement. The characteristics of SRM arrangements are presented in the Table S2. The impact of the composition of the SRM arrangement at 15 h of reaction is illustrated in Fig. 4 (the evolution of the CO conversion and the product selectivities versus the time on stream is presented in Fig. S5). The conversion of CO as a function of the M2 proportion presents a volcano-type profile (Fig. 4a). No activity is observed for M2 and little for M1 (XCO=11.2% with WHSV=5 L.h-1.g-1), while their combination demonstrates synergy, with a maximal CO conversion (XCO=54.1%, which is much higher than the CO conversions obtained with the LB arrangements) located around 50% of M2 proportion. When the M2 proportion increases (see Fig. 4b), the HC (mostly C3H6) selectivity quickly increases (until a plateau around 50% of M2 content) at the expense of the CH4 selectivity while the CO2 selectivity is constant for all the catalytic tests (≈ 40%). The proportion of paraffins also presents a volcano-type profile with a maximum located around 50% of M2. With the same approach as the LB arrangements, it is possible to estimate the gain of CO conversion (denoted XCOgain), for each SRM composition (using Eq.3 with XCOM1 = xM1 × 11.2, where xM1 and 11.2 represent the M1 mass fraction (see Table S2) in the corresponding SRM catalyst and the CO conversion of the M1 catalyst alone at WHSV= 5 L.h-1.g-1, respectively). The XCOgain for the SRM arrangements (see Fig. 4a) presents, also, a volcano-type profile with a maximum located around 50% of M2. In order to validate the M1–M2 proximity hypothesis (directly observed with the LB arrangements), it is necessary to answer this question: ‘what is the influence of the SRM catalyst composition on the M1-M2 proximity responsible for CO conversion?’. 3.3 Sphere contact quantification model in randomly packed binary mixtures for SRM arrangement To investigate whether the volcano-curve profile of the XCOgain, for the SRM arrangements, can be explained by the number of contacts between M1 and M2 as postulated, it is necessary to quantify it in a dense packing of randomly distributed binary spheres (simplified representation of the SRM arrangement in Fig. 5a with rM1=rM2, it was also assumed that the grain size of M1 and M2 did not change during the reduction) as well as in mixtures of different compositions, according with the methodology used in our previous study to determine the concentration of number of contacts between two materials [12]. With the statistical and geometric approach of the Dodds model [16,17], it is possible to easily describe the texture of a 3D polydisperse random mixture. The Dodds model assumes that each particle constituting the polydisperse mixture is in contact with all its neighbors. This basic hypothesis allows to divide the space into tetrahedral subunits ijkl (i, j, k and l representing the indices of the species constituting the four vertices of a tetrahedron), containing a part of vacuum and each vertex being the center of a given particle. A binary random mixture (composed of 2 families of type 1 and 2 particles, representing M1 and M2, respectively for this study) has 5 types of tetrahedral subunits (1111, 1112, 1122, 1222, and 2222, Fig. 5b). These different tetrahedral subunits are geometrically fully characterized with the angles a, b and c at the summit i, the spherical angles α , β and γ and the area AT of the spherical triangle (ABC) [18]. The geometry of such a tetrahedral subunit is completely described by the radii of the four spheres forming it (ri, rj, rk et rj). By knowing the particles radii and their distributions in number, it is possible to determine coordination numbers, porosity, and distribution of the different contact types in the polydisperse mixture. In the spirit of the Dodds model, model calculations were performed. A mathematical model was developed in order to determine the concentration of number of contacts between M1–M1, M2–M2, and M1–M2 (denoted [NC11], [NC22], and [NC12] and expressed in number of contacts per gram of catalyst) for any composition of the SRM catalyst (see Fig. 5c, all the details of the proposed model are presented in the supporting information in the section “Description of the contact model”). In order to have a representative view of the impact of the M1-M2 contacts in the XCOgain, we compared the evolution of the normalized concentration of number of contacts between M1–M2 with the normalized XCOgain as a function of the M2 proportion in the catalyst (Fig. 5d). It clearly appears that the obtained volcano curve for the concentration of number of contacts between M1 and M2 with a maximum at 50% M2 is identical to the one obtained for the normalized XCOgain. This result validates the contact–reactivity relationship hypothesis. 3.4 Reduced SRM arrangement structure and morphology We observed that the CO conversion is dramatically affected by the SRM catalyst composition, and therefore by the amount of M1-M2 contacts present in the hybrid materials. We investigated the structure and textural parameters for the best CO conversion catalyst (SRM(0.50)) to understand the nature of M1-M2 contacts. The XRD diffractogram at the fresh plotted in Fig. S6a is a linear combination of the M1 and M2 ones. After reduction, it corresponds to a combination of the diffractogram of reduced M1 and to the one of SAPO-34 for which the peaks are slightly shifted to the low angles (Fig. S6b). This shift could be due to cationic exchange within the zeotype. [19,20] The morphology of the reduced SRM(0.50) catalyst obtained by FEG-SEM measurements is presented in Fig. 6 (see also Fig. S7 in supporting Information for the complete EDX mapping analysis). The reduced catalyst behaves like a dense packing of randomly distributed binary grains with grain sizes similar to those of the fresh hybrid catalyst (Fig. 6a), which agrees with the starting point of our theoretical model (Fig. 5a). In order to differentiate the nature of each catalyst grain, a mapping of the main characteristic elements of M1 and M2 (Cu (in red) and P (in yellow), respectively) was carried out (Fig. 6b). It can be seen that, after the reduction, this granular mixture includes not only conventional contacts between the grains of M1 and M2 (as one might expect), but also a decoration of the surface of the grains of M1 by microcubes of M2 (see Fig. 6b and c)) and also a decoration of the surface of the grains of M2, in smaller proportions, by particles of M1 (Fig. 6b and d). A generic structure for reduced SRM catalysts is schematically presented in Fig. 6e. These grain decorations optimize the intimacy between M1 and M2 (M1/M2 interphase) which is promote the elimination of the restriction of methanol synthesis by the thermodynamic equilibrium shift and therefore increase of the CO conversion. 3.5 Characterization of the M1-M2 contacts The quantity of interphases between M1 and M2 can be determined, indirectly, using the properties of a Cu exchanged SAPO-34 synthesis method, generally used for the selective catalytic reduction with ammonia (NH3-SCR) [19]. This method, named solid-state ion-exchange (SSIE), consists in mixing copper oxide with SAPO-34 and heating it at low temperature (T < 250 °C) under an atmosphere of NH3, which leads to the diffusion of metal ions in the zeolite [19]. The mobility of Cu is proposed to be related to the formation of complexes [Cu(I)(NH3)x]+ (x ≥ 2). Indeed, these linear complexes have a diameter similar to that of an NH3 molecule, thus allowing these species to easily penetrate into the porous system of the zeolite and thus to improve the Cu exchange. One can thus easily imagine that if one carries out this method with our materials (LB and SRM arrangements), the mobility of Cu should increase with the concentration of contact between M1 and M2. The use of NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) on our materials allows not only to perform the SSIE process during the NH3 adsorption step, but also to indirectly quantify the amount of Cu exchanged in M2 (and therefore a representation of M1-M2 contact concentration). Fig. 7a shows the NH3-TPD profiles on LB and SRM arrangements (the dimensions of our NH3-TPD reactor did not allow us to perform the measurements for the 8LB(7) and 10LB(9) arrangements). These profiles are characterized by three desorption peaks: a low temperature (LT) peak at ∼200 °C (assigned to NH3 adsorbed to Lewis acid sites [21–27]), an intermediate temperature (IT) peak at 250–350 °C (corresponding to NH3 adsorbed on Cu-sites [21–25] created on the zeolite because Cu2+ cations could exchange with the H+ in zeolites partially, introducing some cations to the framework [28,29]) and a high temperature (HT) peak (>400 °C, attributed to NH3 adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites i.e. formation of NH4 + [20–24]). NH3-TPD of reduced SRM(0.50) followed by DRIFT spectroscopy (Fig. S8) confirmed the presence of Lewis acid sites (bands at 3385–3335, 3275, 1622, 1274 and 1219 cm-1) and Brønsted acid sites (3270, 1490–1450 cm-1) as well as NH3 adsorbed on Cu+ sites on SAPO-34 (3184 cm-1). A detailed attribution is provided in the supporting information. In order to better understand the shape of the LB and SRM arrangements NH3-TPD profiles, measurements were carried out on different masses of M1 and M2 alone. From these new profiles, it was possible to simulate theoretical NH3-TPD profiles, corresponding to mixtures of M1 +M2 without contacts (M1 +M2(x), where x represents the M2 content), using linear combination from the characteristic M1 and M2 profiles to the masses of the different LB and SRM arrangements used. The theoretical profiles obtained are shown in Fig. 7a. When the M2 catalyst is associated with the M1 catalyst without contact, it is observed that the experimental profile of 2LB(0) is an exact copy of the profile of M1 +M2(0.50) simulated profile (the total acidity measured for 2LB(0) of 1230 µmol g-1 is in perfect agreement with the value calculated for M1 +M2(0.50) of 1238 µmol g-1). When both catalysts are in contact (2LB(1), 4LB(3), 6LB(5) and SRM arrangements), the experimental profiles are no in agreement with the simulated profiles. An increase in the intensity of the IT peak (corresponding to NH3 adsorbed at Cu-sites) and an increase in the total acidity are observed, indicating a change in behavior linked to the migration of Cu within the zeolite. Fig. 7b shows the results of subtractions between experimental profiles (for the 2LB(1), 4LB(3), 6LB(5) and SRM arrangements) with the corresponding simulated profiles. We observe not only the presence of the peak at intermediate temperature at 340 °C (IT1) but also the appearance of a new peak close to 400 °C (IT2). As demonstrated by Chen et al. [30], species that contribute to the IT1 and IT2 peaks could be the decomposition of the [Cu(I)(NH3)2]+ and [Cu(II)(OH)(NH3)3]+ complexes, respectively. In order to have a representative view of the effect of the contact between M1 and M2 over the Cu migration, the total concentration of both peaks (IT1 and IT2) versus the number of contacts in LB arrangements and versus the M2 content in SRM arrangements are shown in Fig. 8a and b, respectively. It clearly appears that the evolutions of the concentration of new peaks are identical to those obtained for XCOgain of LB and SRM arrangements (in Figs. 3a and 4a). The evolution of XCOgain obtained with the LB and SRM arrangements scales linearly with the concentrations of new peaks, with an interception to zero (see Fig. 8c). This result clearly evidences that the NH3-TPD measurements can be used to quantify contacts between M1 and M2 for one type of arrangement. 4 Conclusion In order to evaluate the effect of the proximity between Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 and SAPO-34 in the conversion of CO into hydrocarbons, different catalytic bed dispositions (LB and SRM) of both components have been adopted. When the SAPO-34 catalyst was associated with the Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst (LB arrangement), without contact, CO conversion has not changed compared to the test with the M1 catalyst alone. However, the disappearance of methanol and DME was observed in favor of hydrocarbons (with a significant selectivity toward CH4 and CO2). When both catalysts were in contact (LB arrangement), an increase of CO conversion and HC selectivity and a decrease of CH4 selectivity were observed. This phenomenon is amplified with the increase of the contact concentration. In order to improve the CO conversion, different SRM of Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 and SAPO-34 were made. The impact of the composition of the SRM hybrid catalyst was investigated and shown a volcano-like profile for CO conversion as a function of M2 content in the catalyst. To elucidate the effect of composition on CO conversion a mathematical model for Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 and SAPO-34 contact quantification, based on a geometrical and statistical approach allowing the textural description of a random polydisperse medium, was developed. The experimental results were compared with theoretical calculations. A direct correlation was found between theory and experiment. The density of contact between Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 and SAPO-34 was identified as the key factor for the catalytic performances (contact-activity relationships). Finally, the knowledge of the contact morphology, determined by FEG-SEM, allowed proposing the NH3-TPD as the concentration of contact characterization method. coredata.dc:description: A series of hybrid catalysts with different catalytic bed dispositions (layer bed and simple random mixture) of Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 and SAPO-34 have been adopted and evaluated in syngas conversion into light C2-C4 hydrocarbons. An effect of the proximity between the two solids on the CO hydrogenation activity was demonstrated. A sphere contact quantification model was developed to estimate the concentration of contact between them for any simple random mixture. Comparing the evolution of gain of CO conversion (or hydrocarbon yield) with the theoretical results, it was shown that the density of contact was identified as the key factor for the catalytic performances (contact-activity relationship). Finally, the knowledge of the contact morphology, determined by FEG-SEM, allowed proposing the NH3-TPD as method characterizing the concentration of contact.
coredata.dc:title: Syngas conversion into light hydrocarbons over bifunctional catalyst: Effect of the density of contact between Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 and SAPO-34
